But nuance is tough in interviews. I'm arguing that men are to be "keepers of the garden", and that means protecting the vulnerable, creating conditions for little things to grow and thrive.

It's something we can do, even "avid indoorsmen" like me. And those around us benefit.

name: Brant Hansen
description:
Author. Radio guy. Aspie. Simultaneously too serious AND too goofy. Latest book here: https://t.co/FSpVeFoBOr
Advocate for the amazing @cureintl
tweet:
Amidst all the deconstruction (some of which is very helpful!) I'm trying to construct a vision for masculinity that's life-giving to all around. 

It's not a "MAN UP YOU GUYS!!!" kind of book. I hope it's deeper and better and more thoughtful...

description:

Forgiveness is freedom.

tweet:
The church is too good to "go out of business." 

It is to be a movement, a family, an outpost of the Kingdom.

Brothers and sisters don't go "out of business." You might have nothing, but... still brother and sister!

A view of "church as business" is a very low view of church.

name: Brant Hansen
description:
Author. Radio guy. Aspie. Simultaneously too serious AND too goofy. Latest book here: https://t.co/FSpVeFoBOr
Advocate for the amazing @cureintl
tweet:
@dandarling I hear you! I don't actually want churches to close. That's my point: I don't think they should have to.

But if they're really a business, it's a problem. Businesses have customers. Believers aren't customers. Disciples aren't customers. Brothers and sisters aren't customers.

name: Brant Hansen
description:
Author. Radio guy. Aspie. Simultaneously too serious AND too goofy. Latest book here: https://t.co/FSpVeFoBOr
Advocate for the amazing @cureintl
tweet:
@dandarling @RealAndreaC Agreed! There are a LOT of awesome people using their pastoral gifts out there.

There are a lot of people laboring in the church without being paid. Many people leading without pay. If someone has a gift to teach or lead, I hope they will do that whether it's their career or not

name: Brant Hansen
description:

This isn't church-bashing. In a way, it's the opposite. I believe things are changing. I'm here for it. Many people are asking great questions. Others are making changes. 

The world--a world that God so loves--needs us to function as families, not businesses.

name: Brant Hansen
description:
Author. Radio guy. Aspie. Simultaneously too serious AND too goofy. Latest book here: https://t.co/FSpVeFoBOr
Advocate for the amazing @cureintl
tweet:
Thankful for leaders who open to changing the status quo. Yes, our consumer culture has "done church" a certain way (a very costly way) for a long time. But things can change.  We don't have to spend 80% on operational costs. 

Discipleship doesn't have to be so expensive.

Advocate for the amazing @cureintl
tweet:
1. God loves us.

2. If we say we love HIM, and want to give Him a gift - He's clear what He wants: Take care of people who can do nothing for you.

3. If we give Him other gifts - like music - but ignore this, He doesn't want those other gifts. He thinks they're annoying.

name: Brant Hansen
description:
Author. Radio guy. Aspie. Simultaneously too serious AND too goofy. Latest book here: https://t.co/FSpVeFoBOr
Advocate for the amazing @cureintl
tweet:
I don't think I have to be in poverty to do what God wants. Not at all.

But I absolutely HAVE to identify with the poor, to make the weak, rejected, or unwanted my "team." If God identifies with them (and He does) I need to do that, too.

An unexpected bonus: Extreme joy.

name: Brant Hansen
description:
Author. Radio guy. Aspie. Simultaneously too serious AND too goofy. Latest book here: https://t.co/FSpVeFoBOr
Advocate for the amazing @cureintl
tweet:
Yes, God has a "love language." It's clear in the Bible:

It's caring for people who can't do anything for us. Orphans. The sick. Widows. The weak. And not to enhance our "good person" resume or make political points, but specifically because we love Him. 

That's what He wants.

I prefer "cracklin' fresh" - more positive!

Actually, I just kinda hate this.

It’s much, much harder. It takes work. But it’s immeasurably healthier for body and soul. It’s freeing.

It’s called forgiveness.

So yeah. Go for it. "Anger lives in the lap of fools." - Eccl. 7:9
